Award.AwardTitle: CyberSEES: Type 2: Collaborative Research: Cyber-infrastructure and Technologies to Support Large-Scale Wildlife Monitoring and Research for Wildlife and Ecology Sustainability

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Minimizing the impact of human actions on wildlife is a priority for conservation biology. Distributed motion-sensitive cameras, or camera traps, are popular tools for monitoring wildlife populations. Recent work has shown that camera trap surveys can be expanded to large scales by crowdsourcing through citizen science, producing big data sets needed to evaluate the effect of sustainability strategies on wildlife populations. However, these large-scale surveys create millions of photographs that create new challenges for data processing and quality control.

This project seeks to develop advanced computing technologies for cloud-based large-scale data sensing, analysis, annotation, management, and preservation for wildlife and ecological sustainability to inform effective resource management, decision-making, and polices on human actions to protect wildlife and natural resources. Specifically, the project aims to: (1) explore a citizen scientist-based approach and system for large-scale sustainable data collection; (2) develop deep-learning based fine-grain animal species recognition from large data sets and automated content annotation; (3) study cloud-based computing with thin-client access and resource allocation for scalable deployment and easy access by citizen scientists; and (4) develop a comprehensive data annotation quality monitoring and control framework with tightly coupled computer annotation, crowd-sourcing, and expert review to ensure a high scientific standard of data quality. These tools will be integrated into the eMammal infrastructure to study three questions on wildlife sustainability: energy development, housing development, and wildlife harvest. These tools will also be available to other wildlife researchers using the eMammal system, enabling an improved understanding how humans can live sustainably with wildlife.

Collaborative wildlife monitoring and tracking at large geographical and time scales will contribute to the understanding of complex dynamics of wildlife systems, and provide important scientific evidence for informed decisions and effective solutions to sustainability issues in wildlife environments. This project will provide unique, exciting, and interdisciplinary opportunities for mentoring graduate students and involving K-12 and undergraduate students into professionally guided research. The citizen science approach used in this project should accommodate hundreds of students in research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was interested in relationships between humans and wildlife, recognizing the need to find sustainable solutions to ensure the well-being of wildlife systems that are critical to our natural environment and national economy.  Outdoor recreation is the third largest section of our economy, and much of that is aimed at wildlife watching or wildlife hunting.  Further, hunting provides a sustainable source of food, recreation, and income for millions. However, modern wildlife populations are threatened by a myriad of challenges including habitat loss, climate change, emerging diseases, and conflict with people or their domestic animals.  Conservation science can provide solutions to many of these challenges, but wildlife managers need up to date information on the status and distribution of species.  Obtaining this annual data on wildlife populations at large scales is a great challenge.  The goal of this project was to develop new technologies to enable enriched wildlife monitoring through a combination of new artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms to process camera traps images, new data management infrastructure for wildlife biologists, real-world data sets on sustainability research topics, and new statistical tools to make the most of these large data sets.

 

Modern digital camera traps have great potential to monitor wildlife populations, but as biologists start setting enough sensors to get good resolution they run into a new challenge of having too many photographs to process, and no good tools that can scale to manage the data.  We developed new AI algorithms to automatically process these photo collections.  First, these tools automatically detect where an animal is in the picture and place a bounding box around it.  Second, these tools use our massive libraries of camera trap images already tagged by humans to train algorithms to recognize what species is in the bounding box.  We have published these results in a variety of peer reviewed publications, and also used them to win the iWildCam 2019 camera trap image classification challenge. Finally, we shared our results with industry partners who have incorporated them into production level tools for scientist to use: Microsoft?s Megadetector and Google?s Wildlife Insights tool.

 

As part of this work we also supported the continued development of the eMammal cyberinfrastructure for managing camera trap data, and the creation of the next-gen tool for this purpose - Wildlife Insights. Furthermore, we used eMammal to collect a variety of datasets directly related to sustainability and wildlife populations, each with their own associated research questions.  As part of the NC Candid Critters project we worked with Citizen Scientists to survey >4000 locations across all 100 counties in North Carolina, including suburban, rural, and wild locations.  As part of the ongoing Snapshot USA project we worked with professors and undergraduates to survey >1200 locations across all 50 United States.  As part of the ongoing Mast and Mammals project we surveyed ~400 locations across eight NEON sites. As part of the Sustainable Ranches project we worked with cattlemen to survey ~280 sites across 5 ranches. All of these data are processed and managed through eMammal and will be made available after we publish our initial papers, and eventually archived at Wildlife Insights.

 

Camera trap data are so useful to scientists and conservationists because they record fundamental data on location, timing, and species.  However, traditional analyses have considered only one of these data types at a time. We have developed two new statistical approaches to make the most of these data. First, we developed a model that allows for spatial interactions between multiple (>2) species.  Second, we developed a ?continuous time occupancy model? that allows the consideration of both space and time (i.e. do specie use different habitats at different time of day), as well as species interactions in time (i.e. does a prey avoid a site after a predator passes by) and in space.

 

This project has made major advances in our ability to monitor wildlife and understand the sustainability of our actions. Our methodological advances in AI, research infrastructure, and statistical tools are now available to a wide range of scientists, and citizen scientists, for their own work. Our own research into sustainability of human actions has informed on a variety of topics including cattle ranching, hunting, hiking, outdoor cats, back-yard practices, and land protection. All data are (or will soon be) publicly available, as are the millions of amazing animal pictures, which we share through the eMammal website, and social media. This project was part of the graduate training for 6 students and involved dozens of undergraduates.  In addition, it has been incorporated into engagement activities and exhibitions at the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences.
